narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: How to write well-developed arguments for history papers, how to think critically about religion, how to analyze texts and course themes.

We got to read all the best hits of the Catholic Intellectual Tradition, and learned to analyze the continuity of many themes throughout them. This course will show you how diverse and beautiful the Catholic Faith really is.

An overview of how ideas within the Catholic tradition evolved through engagement with primary texts, covering topics ranging from the Bible, Augustine and Aquinas, early patristic Church fathers, monasticism, scholasticism, mystics, figures in the Reformation and the Enlightenment, to modern 20th and 21st century encyclicals and autobiographies

In this course, students gain insight into the critical ideas, thinkers, and texts within the Catholic tradition. The format reminded me of the Directed Studies program (I'm an alum), but with a greater emphasis on lecture/historical context and somewhat less on group discussion. The syllabus proceeds from early Church history all the way to the present, offering close engagement with primary source texts each week. You will learn to trace the development of Christian ideas over time and make connections across centuries. Very rewarding!

I developed a strong understanding of the writings, figures, and beliefs that made up the Catholic intellectual tradition. I learned how to engage with difficult texts and bring them into conversation with one another.

I gained an understanding of Catholic texts, authors, and philosophies throughout the history of the Catholic Church. This is an AMAZING course- not only did I learn quite a bit from all of the primary texts we examined, I also found myself relating to Catholicism in an entirely reimagined way.
Excellent ovreview of Catholic Intellectual tradition focusing on certain key texts.
Deep knowledge of the history of the Catholic Church and the intellectuals who have shaped the way we now think about Catholic doctrine.
Knowledge about Catholic thought from the early Church to the present.

I found this course to be incredible! I cannot tell you how much I learned about the overall Catholic tradition and this class more than anything else comes up in my life. I truly believe this class has made me better understand the world. Although if you are someone who wants to spend extra time diving into a topic know that this class moves very quickly with little time to truly discuss any topic (Granted it has to get through a lot of years)
I developed an awareness and appreciation of the Catholic intellectual tradition, as well as helpful strategies and tips for paper-writing.

This class has enabled me to better understand the philosophical underpinnings of the catholic faith in a way that is both charitable and critical, therefore contextualizing two millennia of human history given the broad influence of religion in all spheres of life and allowing me to track how these ideas have evolved and changed. The course also provides a strong grounding in writing and critical thinking, especially for prospective history majors.

Working knowledge of the Catholic intellectual tradition including common saints, theological beliefs, and counter thinkers
Understanding of the development of Catholic doctrine from the Gospels to modern encyclicals, from priests and nuns to bishops and popes

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: amazing professor, guest lecturers, and TFs; visual aids during lectures; interesting reading assignments

Weaknesses: sometimes there is too much reading to get to in one week; no break during lectures, some days it is hard to stay focused the whole time

How it could be improved: avoid an overload of reading (less reading makes me more compelled to do it all, but sometimes I get overwhelmed seeing so much and don't know where to even start); break up the lecture by showing a video or asking a poll question or even just saying take two minutes to stretch

The course presents its themes from the very beginning and chooses material that reflects these well. However, considering how large some jumps in time periods were, making connections from one week to the next can be very tough.

This is an excellent, well-structured course. You can see how the professors who designed the course (Prof. Eire and Prof. Brenzel) carefully selected each text to provide a coherent narrative of the Catholic intellectual tradition that is easy to follow (while still interesting and challenging enough), even for someone new to the tradition. Each primary text selected provides key ideas within the Catholic tradition or challenges to it that allows you to gain a broad understanding of the tradition over two millennia (which is not an easy thing to do at all in a course).

This course has many strengths. The frequent guest lecturers offered engaging perspectives across a broad range of disciplines and academic expertise. The weekly discussion sections offered an excellent complement to the lectures. The exams were very manageable (one-hour passage ID) and I actually enjoyed putting the various texts we had read in conversation with one another. The essays also offered an opportunity to practice this skill in more detail. No improvements to suggest!
some of the reading is very very dense and I don't think they contributed to my understanding of the essence of the course.

This course's strength was its breadth. We covered so much and I truly felt like a got a strong understanding of the general ark of the Catholic intellectual tradition. However, I did feel that I was lacking depth on some texts. This would've been helpful for work like Thomas Aquinas' Suma Theologica and Augustine's Confessions, which we kept returning to throughout the course but I never felt like I fully had a grasp on.
Strengths and weaknesses were a bit contradictory- I really liked that there were multiple lecturers, but Professor Eires lectures were always the most engaging, so I wish he had lectured more.
Strengths: great choice of readings, manageable reading assigned every week, guest lecturers also added to the course.

Carlos is an excellent lecturer, and the guest lecturers he sometimes brings in are highly respected and intelligent themselves. Certainly the strength of this course  is Carlos Eire himself, he is a brilliant mind and makes lectures entertaining and engaging. I wish all of my teachers were as cool as he is.

Strengths: Carlos Eire is a great professor and very easy to follow, and the actual work assigned wasn't difficult.
Weaknesses: Some of the readings were especially long and could have been cut down, and some weeks had significantly more readings than others. I think the week on Dorothy Day and Thomas Merton in particular seemed lopsided relative to the much larger quantity of reading in other weeks. Some of the guest lecturers also didn't use slides so it was harder to follow.

I would say a weakness of the class is the long readings, the lectures that include no participation, and the lack of time to fully dive into any topic. The strengths would be the discussion sections and how interesting the course is.
This was my favorite course this semestervery organized, and my TF was helpful and encouraging. Professor Eire was so knowledgeable and enthusiastic, and I loved the guest lectures too!

Strengths: 
Syllabus includes a manageable workload and breadth of Catholic and non-Catholic primary and secondary sources 
Very structured lectures with PowerPoints which are made available after class
Reviews for midterms and final
Clear expectations for assignments, testing dates, and lecture content 
Cohesive lecture presentations including guest lecturers

Weaknesses: 
Covers literally 2000years of content...hard to cover any one thing in depth

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Virtual lecture and section went pretty well. I liked that Prof. Eire used a PowerPoint during his lectures. It was hard to stay focused when guest lecturers didn't have a visual aid. I would've loved if Prof. Eire had weekly office hours instead of office hours by appointment for the opportunity to talk to him more.
The combination of virtual lectures and section worked well throughout the semester. The essay assignments and exams using the Lockdown browser were also easy to navigate.
This course was well-executed in virtual form. Recorded lectures were very helpful and I listened to many again in review!
The live lectures were great but sometimes a little too fast paced. I also enjoyed the discussion sections with our TAs to help clarify our readings and what we heard in lecture.

The lecture recordings were helpful on multiple occasions, especially when I was studying. However, it was difficult to engage in the lectures as much as I wanted to, because there wasnt really a way to feel engaged if I didnt have a specific question to ask about something.
Live lectures helped because of the ability to ask questions at end and the small size of the seminars also helped remain focused.

Definitely having slides up helped, and this course could be improved if all guest lecturers screenshared their slides as well. Otherwise, I think lecturers are particularly hard to keep with during virtual learning.

I think small discussion sections were successful. Mine was only 5 people large so by the end I truly felt like I knew everyone. In lectures, there are no participation which can be a little tedious in zoom.
The virtual lectures, discussions, and exams all worked well for me. I dont think I would change anything.
Guest lectures were great and posting lecture slides and recordings helped a ton

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, Catholic or not. This course has helped me understand my faith more and understand the history of Christianity for the most part.

YES! Prof. Eire is an awesome teacher and expert on this topic. For anyone with experience/interest in Catholicism or Christianity generally, this course gives a great foundation. You read all of the "core" texts: Dante, Augustine, Thomas Merton, the Gospels. There are some really knowledgeable guest speakers, and small sections make for a great discussion. This course has a low workload, with just a couple of short papers and a midterm/final that are just a few reading IDs. Definitely take this class if you can.
Definitely! I learned so much and I really loved the professor and TFs. Very interesting discussions and readings, and I enjoyed the class a lot.
Yes, everyone should learn about the Catholic Faith in its fullest and most beautiful forms.

Absolutely! This is an excellent course. You should take it especially if you've interacted, engaged with, or consider yourself part of the Catholic tradition. You will really gain a much deeper understanding and true appreciation for the richness of the tradition and the ways in which it has changed, been challenged, and stayed the same through history. This is a class about intellectual history so you will learn about ideas and debates within the Catholic tradition over millennia (e.g. touching on the earliest church debates about Jesus, or natural law), rather than church structure, modern day politics, or socio-political history if you're more into that, but engaging with these ideas are very worthwhile. The texts can be challenging at times, but the professor, TA, and section are there to help you through it.

I am not exaggerating when I say that this class changed my life. I had never come in contact with the depth of this tradition that I have (nominally) belonged to my whole life, but have only recently begun to pursue in earnest. I am all the more inspired to inquire into my faith now after encountering the vast scope of ideas that have endured for millennia and shaped the Catholic Church for what it is today.

I would recommend this class to anyone who is looking to learn more about catholicism or christianity. It is a very well organized crash course in the intellectual origins and evolution of the Christian/Catholic faith, which underpins Western thought in general quite substantially. Some of the reading gets dense, some of it is interesting, close reading isn't super necessary so I would say it is manageable.

I would absolutely recommend this course if this is a topic they're interested in. This was my first ever religious studies class and it was excellent way for me to be introduced to the subject and I felt really confident in a lot of the knowledge I learned.

Yes, absolutely. This course shaped my understanding of Catholicism so deeply. This course is great for anyone, regardless of their religious background. An understanding of the religion is not assumed in any means. Personally, however, I found myself getting more engaged in my faith as a whole after/while taking this course.
Yes, it was well-organized and well-taught.
For sure. Take this class if you are Catholic, thinking of converting, or just interested in Catholic history in general. I cannot recommend this course highly enough.
Yes, if you are interested in Christianity. As far as lectures go, it's not a gut, but the workload is extremely manageable.

Yes! I loved this course. I truly feel like I learned a great deal that is easily applicable to my other studies and the world around me. Yes, there is a bit of reading but the discussion helps anyone get through it. I really really enjoyed the course.

I would definitely recommend this class to other students! If you are at all interested in religious studies, or, like me, are interested in intellectual history but are more familiar with the secular side of things, this course provides a wonderful survey of some of the fundamental texts of the Catholic intellectual tradition. Professor Eire is extremely knowledgeable and enthusiastic, as are the guest lecturers.

I would recommend this course to any student, especially those who are interested in majoring in history or philosophy and those seeking to better understand their faith or lack thereof, whether they are Catholics themselves or want to better understand Catholicism in juxtaposition with their present beliefs. It is interesting, engaging, and edifying.

Would highly recommend this course to anyone interested in Catholicism (institutionally, theologically, etc) and its development over time and with/against change. It covers some very foundational works and gives a great introduction to higher level courses. Its great for non Catholics as well, as it covers the pre-Christian thinkers, Enlightenment, Protestantism, and modern thinkers
